An introduction to the cassowaryr package

Source: vignettes/cassowaryr.Rmd
cassowaryr.Rmd

About

The cassowaryr package provides functions to compute scagnostics on pairs of numeric variables in a data set.

The term scagnostics refers to scatter plot diagnostics, originally described by John and Paul Tukey. This is a collection of techniques for automatically extracting interesting visual features from pairs of variables. This package is an implementation of graph theoretic scagnostics developed by Wilkinson, Anand, and Grossman (2005) in pure R.

Installation

The package can be installed from CRAN using

install.packages("cassowaryr")

and from GitHub using

remotes::install_github("numbats/cassowaryr")

to install the development version.

Examples 

library(cassowaryr)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

# pick examples
exampledata <- datasaurus_dozen %>%
  filter(dataset==c("v_lines", "circle", "dots", "away")) 
#> Warning in dataset == c("v_lines", "circle", "dots", "away"): longer object
#> length is not a multiple of shorter object length

#plot them
exampledata %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=x,y=y, colour=dataset))+
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap("dataset") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

We can calculate a select group of scagnostic for every group in a dataset.

#compute scagnostics
scag_data <- exampledata %>%
  group_by(dataset) %>%
  summarise(calc_scags(x,y, scags=c("clumpy2", "outlying", "monotonic"))) 

scag_data %>%
  knitr::kable(digits=4, align="c")
dataset outlying clumpy2 monotonic
away 0.0000 0.1501 0.0875
circle 0.0000 0.0000 0.0499
dots 0.3487 0.9829 0.0391
v_lines 0.0000 0.4876 0.0801

We can also a select group of scagnostics for every pairwise variable combination of a data set.

data(pk)
calc_scags_wide(pk[,2:5], scags=c("outlying","clumpy","monotonic")) %>%
  knitr::kable(digits=4, align="c")
Var1 Var2 outlying clumpy monotonic
MDVP:Fhi(Hz) MDVP:Fo(Hz) 0.4119 0.9339 0.7956
MDVP:Flo(Hz) MDVP:Fo(Hz) 0.1722 0.8784 0.3236
MDVP:Flo(Hz) MDVP:Fhi(Hz) 0.3361 0.9707 0.0956
MDVP:Jitter(%) MDVP:Fo(Hz) 0.2888 0.9153 0.2697
MDVP:Jitter(%) MDVP:Fhi(Hz) 0.5414 0.9217 0.0978
MDVP:Jitter(%) MDVP:Flo(Hz) 0.4300 0.9117 0.4067

We can use either of these generated data sets to find the top scagnostic for each variable, or the top variable for each scagnostic. This is an example of the top scagnsotic for each pair.

scag_data %>%
  top_pairs() %>%
  knitr::kable(digits=4, align="c")
dataset scag value
away clumpy2 0.1501
circle monotonic 0.0499
dots clumpy2 0.9829
v_lines clumpy2 0.4876
